abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Southern Governorates
            Agricultural Privatization Project for Yemen were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: Combining
            high risk with high complexity compounds overall project
            risk levels. The design for achieving intended project
            results should not be overly dependent upon unpredictable
            inputs from other projects or agencies. Demand-driven,
            community-based approaches need to be designed in ways that
            are as streamlined and realistic as possible, taking into
            account community time constraints. Supervision should pay
            close attention to implementation performance and act
            quickly to modify the project if implementation is lagging
            due to poor design or an overly difficult political context.
            When major modifications have taken place (components
            drastically reduced and/or increased, major new activities
            added), formal restructuring should be seriously considered.
            While the project had targets concerning project benefits
            for women and certain outputs were achieved, more specific
            strategies and focused attention on reaching this target
            group could have increased the level of outcomes attained.
